title: 114_hr5388
content: The "Support for Rapid Innovation Act of 2016" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 introduces cybersecurity research and development projects under the Homeland Security Act of 2002. The Under Secretary for Science and Technology supports research, development, testing, and transition of cybersecurity technologies to improve information sharing, analytics, and methodologies for cybersecurity risks and incidents. This includes advancing secure information systems, developing technologies for detecting attacks, and creating mitigation and recovery methodologies. The Under Secretary for Science and Technology supports the development of resilient networks, cybersecurity research tools, technologies to reduce vulnerabilities in industrial control systems, and cyber forensics capabilities. Coordination with non-Federal entities is also emphasized. The Secretary for Science and Technology coordinates activities with the Under Secretary, other relevant Federal departments, industry, and academia. The Under Secretary supports projects through the full life cycle, identifies mature technologies to address cybersecurity gaps, and introduces new cybersecurity technologies through partnerships. The Under Secretary focuses on cybersecurity research with high potential for commercialization and impact on information systems. Definitions for cybersecurity risk, homeland security enterprise, and incident are provided. The text chunk provides definitions for "incident" and "information system" in relation to cybersecurity. It also includes a clerical amendment to the Homeland Security Act of 2002. The text chunk amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to require prior approval from the Secretary for utilizing authority in cybersecurity research and development projects. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to require approval from the Secretary for cybersecurity research and development projects. The Secretary must submit an annual report detailing the projects authorized under this authority. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 now requires approval from the Secretary for cybersecurity research and development projects. The Secretary must submit an annual report detailing the projects authorized under this authority, including funds spent, cost-sharing, outcomes, and audit results. Additionally, a training program must be developed by the Secretary. The Secretary is required to develop a training program for acquisitions staff on utilizing the authority provided. No additional funds are authorized for carrying out this Act and its amendments. The House of Representatives passed the Act on June 21, 2016, as attested by Karen L. Haas, Clerk.
